title: Billy Elliot boys cast for tour of the famous musical
text:
Billy Elliot boys cast for tour of the famous musical By WMNdellis | Posted: October 16, 2015 BILLY ELLIOT THE MUSICAL, London - photo by Alastair Muir (2) Billy Elliot boys cast for tour of the famous musical   Comments (0) 
Four boys have been cast to play the leading role of Billy Elliot in the hit musical of the same name when it tours next year. 
Jessica Ronane, who is the casting director, has seen plenty of budding stars audition over the years and this time is no exception. 
She’s had the role of selecting the leading characters in the show since 2003. 
“We will be touring with four boys who will rotate, just like they do in the West End,” she said. 
“It’s an intensely physical role and they have to look after themselves and also rest.” 
Boys aged nine to 12 can apply for the famous role. 
“They are around 11 years old when they peak,” she said. 
“First and foremost we look for talent, that has to be in abundance. 
“It can be raw talent, that’s fine as we can train them. 
“They have to have a spark and an energy and you can see their potential. Each boy has to have something special you want to watch.” 
In 2006, Liam Mower, James Lomas and George Maguire, the first three boys to play the title role, became the youngest performers ever to have won the Olivier Award for Best Actor with the show also picking up the Best Musical prize. 
“What’s wonderful is the first three boys in the West End have gone on to have great careers,” she said. 
She said that casting budding Billy’s is easier than trying to find young actors to play the part of Michael, Billy’s gay friend. 
“He’s a really delicate part and you have to cast it right,” said Jessica, who also casts for the likes of Matlida and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. 
“Michael has to have good humour and have a vulnerable side, yet be totally charming.! 
The tour, which plays the Theatre Royal Plymouth, from February 24- April 2 tugs at the heartstrings. 
Set in a northern mining town, against the background of the 1984/’85 miners’ strike, Billy’s journey takes him out of the boxing ring and into a ballet class where he discovers a passion for dance that inspires his family and whole community and changes his life forever. 
Acclaimed by audiences and critics alike, Billy Elliot the Musical has now been seen by more than ten million people across five continents and is the recipient of more than 80 awards internationally, including ten Tony Awards and five Olivier Awards. 
“You are supportive of the kid right from the beginning,” said Jessica. 
“He has to overcome so much to pursue his love of dance. You’d have to be made of cold stuff not to be moved. 
“It’s a political story, a story of family and foremost it’s a story about a boy.” 
Tickets can be booked online at www.theatreroyal.com or by calling the Theatre Royal Plymouth Box Office on 01752 267222.
